newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Austria's Klima says EMU a vital project.
newsitem.headline: Austria's Klima says EMU a vital project.

text.p: Austrian Chancellor Viktor Klima said on Friday that European monetary union (EMU) was economically and politically vital for Europe.
Speaking at a European Union summit here, Klima said that the single currency was an "urgently needed economic project" and "a most important political project".
Austria's Klima says EMU a vital project
Klima added that the introduction of the euro currency would be a further step towards strengthening Europe and a step away from breakup, renationalisation and a resurgence of chauvinism.
EU leaders were meeting here to try and put the finishing touches to a new treaty which would create the institutional framework readying the organisation to admit new members from Eastern Europe.

Austria, which joined the EU in 1994, counts among the "hard core" of countries which have shadowed Germany's monetary policy for years to keep its schilling currency stable against the mark, and is seen as likely to join EMU's first wave.

Klima, however, stepped out of line with his counterparts in Bonn by saying recently he hoped Italy would be admitted to the first wave of EMU in 1999. Germany has misgivings about the impact that Italy's lack of a long-term record of fiscal prudence might have on the stability of the euro.
